questions.text: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
questions.solution:
Morbidity is not a demographic process.

Demography refers to the study of the population. Demographic processes include:

  • Fertility
  • Mortality
  • Marriage
  • Migration
  • Social mobility

These processes continuously bring about changes in the population size, composition, and distribution.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the death rate start declining?
questions.solution:
The death rate starts declining in stage 2 or the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the birth rate start declining?
questions.solution:
The birth rate starts declining in stage 3 or the late expanding phase of the demographic cycle.

India is currently in this stage of the demographic cycle.

The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 1 to stage 2 of the demographic cycle.

questions.text:
A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?

Country A:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 38.3 38.3
Death rate 13.7 10.2

Country B:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 12.4 12.3
Death rate 6.7 6.6
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. 

According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate.

In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below. 

The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic cycle of various countries. In which stages of the cycle will she notice an increase and a decrease in the demographic gap respectively?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing in stage 2 and starts decreasing in stage 3.

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rate and death rate which develops when a country undergoes a demographic transition.

In stage 2 of the demographic cycle, the death rate declines but the birth rate remains unchanged. Hence, the demographic gap increases and reaches a maximum by the end of stage 2. In stage 3, both the death rate and birth rate are declining so the demographic gap starts decreasing.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the stage of demographic cycle marked by the red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked stage is the late expanding phase (stage 3) of the demographic cycle. A demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in this stage. 

This refers to the presence of a higher number of economically productive individuals (young and middle-aged adults) in the population due to a higher birth rate in the previous demographic phase (phase 2). India is currently experiencing the demographic gift.

The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap. The death rate declines further and the birth rate falls in this stage.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle will the phenomenon of a demographic trap be maximally seen?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of a demographic trap is seen maximally in the early expanding stage (stage 2).

This phenomenon refers to a period in which there is high fertility and birth rate and a declining death rate. The population grows exponentially in this stage and this growing population exceeds the national or regional carrying capacity. Countries in this stage are said to be caught in a demographic trap.

questions.text: While conducting a field study in a village, you found the birth and death rates of the population to be 42 and 31 respectively. What is the current annual growth rate of this population?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the current annual growth rate is 1.1%.

Here, the birth rate is 42 i.e 42 live births per 1000 population, and the death rate is 31 i.e 31 deaths per 1000 population. 

Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate. So, current annual growth rate = 42-31= 11 per 1000 population or 1.1%.

questions.text: The population of a country is 1 lakh in the year 2000 and its annual growth rate is 2%. By which year will the population of this country become 2 lakhs?
questions.solution:
For the given country, its population would become 2 lakhs i.e, double the population from the year 2000, by the year 2035.

As per the Malthusian growth model, when the annual growth rate is 1%, the population doubles in 70 years. Therefore, when the annual growth rate is 2%, the population will double in 35 years.

The Malthusian growth model/ rule of 70:

Rating Annual growth rate Population doubles in
Slow growth <0.5% >139 years
Moderate growth from 0.5% ~139 years
Rapid growth from 1% 70 years
Very rapid growth from 1.5% approximately 50 years
Explosive growth from 2% 35 years
Explosive growth from 3% 20-25 years

The growth rate of India is estimated at 1% as per 2020 UN data. Therefore, it falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth.

questions.text: You have been tasked with studying the age and sex structure of a population with high rates of female infanticide. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use?
questions.solution:
The age and sex structure of a population may be best represented using a population pyramid.

It is a histogram that shows the distribution of ages across a population. It is divided down the center between male and female members of the population.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.
